events.name: Workshop: A glimpse into TypeScript
events.description:
During this workshop we'll try out TypeScript: a promising technology that brings the power of strict typing into JavaScript. This session will include a brief introduction and a walkthrough of all the main features of TS followed by a practical workshop where we'll set up a simple frontend project.

Since we're actually going to write code on the workshop, please take your laptops with you. You'll need your favourite IDE (Webstorm, IDEA or the free Visual Studio Code will do just fine) and the latest version of Node and Npm. We'll set up the rest.

events.name: Google I/O 2016 Extended

venue.name: OK.ru Office

events.description:
Join us at Google I/O Extended, watch a Google I/O Keynote life stream, discuss the news and eat some snacks in the process. Friendly and Googly atmosphere guaranteed!

events.name: Google I/O Retrospective

venue.name: OK.ru Office
venue.address_1: Pblc Biznesa Centrs , SIA - 23 Ulbrokas iela

events.description:
On this event we will have a retrospective of all the news during I/O event. We will show something, that was only on the backstage.

Also come and grab some swag ;)

Join us!

events.name: Workshop: Dockerization
events.description:
This one you really do not want to miss. During this workshop all of you will have one common goal. Only together you will make an application successfully up and running.

You will write Dockerfiles, building images, configuring Docker Compose, even work with Docker Registry.

Be ready. It will be very active.


Requirements:

‚Ä¢¬†Latest Docker installed (see https://docs.docker.com/engine/installation/). For Mac and Windows see Docker Toolbox.

‚Ä¢¬†Latest Docker Compose installed (see https://docs.docker.com/compose/install/). Skip this if installed¬†Docker Toolbox.

‚Ä¢¬†Git is installed.

‚Ä¢¬†GitHub account.

‚Ä¢¬†Refresh your knowledge of Github Fork+Pull Request workflow.

‚Ä¢¬†Text editor of your choice (atom, vim, sublime, ...).

‚Ä¢¬†docker run hello-world successfully completed.

events.name: Workshop: League of Graphs
events.description:
In this show-and-tell session we‚Äôll find out how Neo4j can make us a professional League of Legends player. First, we‚Äôll import game data into a Neo4j graph. Then we will push the limits of Cypher to uncover hidden secrets that lie in the depth of LoL.

‚Ä¢ Which champions perform best as allies?

‚Ä¢ What is the most effective strategy to advance your champion?

‚Ä¢¬†What enemy team setup is the most dangerous?¬†

This session covers a rarely seen graph domain (gaming) and will provide you will solid, factual advice on how to play LoL.

events.name: Workshop: Firebase - rule all platforms!
events.description:
During this workshop you will explore possibilities of the Firebase in following platforms: iOS, Android and Web (JS). So, if you are one of these - come to the workshop, bring your teammates and let's hack together!

This time format will be really interesting, we will split into groups with developer from each platform and try to bring a truly cross-platform app during the event with Firebase as a backend.

** Please prepare your local environment before the event! Here is the list of requirements for each platform:

Android:

‚Ä¢¬†Device with Android 2.3+ and Google Play Services 9.4.0+

Android Studio 1.5+

‚Ä¢¬†Google Play Services SDK

iOS:

‚Ä¢¬†Mac OS with Xcode 7 installed.

‚Ä¢¬†Basic Swift 2.2 knowledge

Web:

‚Ä¢¬†Google Chrome with Dev Tools

‚Ä¢¬†Text-editor of your choice with code highlight (Atom, Sublime, vim)

‚Ä¢¬†NodeJs v6.3 or higher & NPM installed

events.name: GDG Meetup: Optimizing your Product

venue.name: OK.ru Office
venue.address_1: Pblc Biznesa Centrs , SIA - 23 Ulbrokas iela

events.description:
We're back with our Meetup format: two talks from two awesome speakers!¬†

This time we are visiting OK.ru with two talks on optimizing their products both on the backend and mobile.¬†

- First one from Vitaly Kulikov on Tips and tricks of highly loaded product management¬†(RUS):

This talk is about life of our products. It's about decisions we made, and the way this decisions guide us today. Talk will cover many aspects starting from choosing technological stack, up to monitoring production environment.

- Second talk from¬†Kirill Popov¬†on Working with images on Android (RUS):

I will tell you why we are migrated to Fresco. Why it fits our requirements? How is it works? And how to use it better?

events.name: GDG Riga Meetup:  Digital Marketing: Tool to Reach your Users!
events.description:
Agenda for the Meetup:

‚Ä¢¬†JƒÅnis Birƒ£elis, Data Team Leader at¬†Infinitum8 will present"Plan and Measure your Product Ahead with Digital Marketing".¬†

The talk will focus on how to think about complex marketing/content/measurements and what phases to prepare for in the client cycle.

JƒÅnis is one of the 5 Google Certified Trainers in Latvia. Working closely with others he offers a Web Analytics courses for young and experienced entrepreneurs. During his 3 years experience he was helping others to better understand data and being critical about data interpretations locally and over the world.¬†

‚Ä¢¬†KƒÅrlis Kalni≈Ü≈°, Google Adwords / Analytics Certified Partner will present "How to Define a¬†Digital Marketing Strategy Plan for your Product"

Using digital marketing without a strategic approach is still commonplace. Save Your time and resources by actionable strategy.

KƒÅrlis¬†successfully managed over 100 small,medium and large client digital marketing accounts for 3,5 years¬†

events.name: Coding Dojo: Golang Rally
events.description:
If you are interested to try out Go (Golang) language it's the best chance to do it!

Event will be done in¬†RandoriKata format. There will be one machine, one view, driver and a copilot. Also there will be instructors, that will help in case of lost turn. All of you will try your best as driver or copilot. It will be fun!

Requirements:

‚Ä¢ Good mood

‚Ä¢ Desire to write code

events.name: Coding Dojo: Kotlin Saturday
events.description:
Ruslan Ibragimov,¬†leader of Belorussian Kotlin User Group¬†is going to co-host a¬†Kotlin CodingDojo in Riga! If you always wanted to start with Kotlin or already proficient with it or just wanted to talk to a Kotlin guru join us at this fun event!

Event will be done in¬†RandoriKata format. We will have one PC for everyone and take turns as drivers and a copilots to solve algorithmic tasks with Kotlin. After a proper introduction to the language for guys who had little experience¬†with it, so don't be scared ;)¬†

Preparation: Just bring a good mood and an open mind

Language: Ruslan will host the Dojo in Russian

P.S: Ruslan will also do two great talks about Kotlin at¬†JUG.lv¬†on 15 of December ;)

events.name: Workshop: Kubernetes 101
events.description:
Antons Kranga - Director of Engineering @ Agile Stacks ¬† ¬† ¬†

Antons have got over 15 years of experience in Software Development. He is an experienced Cloud Architect and DevOps evangelist. His passion is to get in touch to the new technologies to discover some area for innovation. ¬†

About the event:

Google Kubernetes which the industry standard for hosting containers. It is fast and reliable (production ready). This workshop will focus on few important aspects of kubernetes including: scheduling the containers, scaling and rolling updates. We are going to build and application, expose it as a container and deploy to the Kubernetets. As well as will touch few operational aspects.¬†

‚Ä¢ No previous Docker knowledge has been required.¬†

‚Ä¢ Participants will use Cloud, however they should be familiar with SSH.¬†

‚Ä¢¬†Basic shell experience is also advisable¬†

events.name: HashCode 2017

venue.name: OK.ru Office
venue.address_1: Pblc Biznesa Centrs , SIA - 23 Ulbrokas iela

events.description:
Hash Code is a team-based programming competition organized by Google. You pick your team and programming language, we pick a real-life engineering problem for you to solve. Are you up for the challenge?

Top scoring teams from the Online Qualification Round will be notified on 28th February 2017 and invited to the Final Round at Google Paris!

What do I need to participate?

!!! Important !!!:¬†You need to register at¬†HashCode website¬†as well.

The only thing you need for the Online Qualification Round is a computer connected to the Internet. We will announce the problem through a YouTube Live Stream, please check that your computer is able to play YouTube videos beforehand. The Judge System will be available as a web application, compatible with recent web browsers. For the rest of your computer setup, you're free to use the tools and programming languages of your choice.

Agenda:

‚Ä¢¬†19:00:Open room

‚Ä¢¬†19:30:Live stream starts

‚Ä¢¬†19:45:Task made available, competition starts

‚Ä¢¬†23:30:End of the competition

More info on https://hashcode.withgoogle.com/

events.name: Kotlin 1.1 Release Party
events.description:
Kotlin 1.1 is released this month with a lot of kool features and improvements! Let's celebrate with a world-wide Kotlin party! We will have 3 great speakers and 3 great topics to enjoy.

1. What‚Äôs new in Kotlin 1.1?

Quick glance over major and the most exciting changes in newest Kotlin release with totally not made up real life examples. Type aliases, delegates, std-lib upgrades and much much more.

By Sergejs Luhmirins, Android developer and Kotlin enthusiast @ FullContact

2. Kotlin in real life

Real life story of migrating a production app to Kotlin. Introduction on how we're using Kotlin in FullContact for Android. Insights you can apply when migrating to Kotlin yourself, and tips to make existing Kotlin code fun to write and easy to read.

By <a>Toms Kusi≈Ü≈°</a>, Android developer @ FullContact

3. KotlinJS - is it a thing?

What if you could write JavaScript in a good way? KotlinJS promises such a thing, but does it deliver? Let‚Äôs discuss

By Alexey Buzdin, Senior developer @ Citadele Bank

events.name: Workshop: METEOR
events.description:
You've heard that meteors are flying around our planet, but have you coded in METEOR? This is you opportunity to do it!

Following workshop will be about METEOR framework. During this workshop you will get knowledge about METEOR fundamentals as:

‚Ä¢ Reactivity

‚Ä¢ Subscriptions

‚Ä¢ etc.

‚Ä¢ Bring your laptop

‚Ä¢¬†Meteor should be¬†installed on your machine

‚Ä¢¬†Good mood

events.name: Google I/O Extended 2017
events.description:
Join us at Google I/O Extended, watch a Google I/O Keynote life stream on the big screen in a Cinema, discuss the news and eat some snacks in the process. Friendly and Googly atmosphere guaranteed! Also we will have our own small lifestreams from San Francisco from our own GDG Riga organizers. ;)

Some wild guessed on big announcements: Android O (Oreo?), updates on Virtual Reality, new Firebase features, new stuff with IoT and AndroidThings, TensorFlow.

https://events.google.com/io/

P.S. Google I/O Livestream will be concluding Riga Dev Days 2017¬†edition, so potentially you could meet a lot of speakers from RDD and discuss with them the new announced stuff.¬†

events.name: Google #IO17 Hands-On Retrospective
events.description:
@SergeyKibish and @Alexey Buzdin were in San Francisco and are going to share their experience from the trip.¬†Presentation will cover: Google Assistant, API.ai, Actions on Google, Android+Kotlin=<3, Android Things (IoT), Web, Machine Learning and TensorFlow news from the I/O (also some news from backstage) (also some news from backstage) as well as share their practical experience they‚Äôve got during this short time.

+ You will hear stories about the trip at whole, visit to Google Office, Intel Party, Computer History Museum and much more.

++ There will be live demonstration of Google Home and how you can program for it

+++ We will order some pizza from http://www.picudarbnica.lv/

events.name: IT Pub Quiz Night
events.description:
Programmers loves to write code but hey, it's Summer, we should relax a bit! And how a proper programmer relaxes? He talks and thinks about code! Simple as that, my friends. 8-)

This time at GDG Riga we will have a special Pub Quiz event about IT, Programming Languages and Frameworks, Platforms, OSes and famous IT people. Gather a team up to 8 people and conquer the IT Quiz Night Tournament! And beware, there will be prizes!

The rules are simple, 5 rounds of pure geekiness with IT related questions, and you can earn one point per correct answer.

The venue this time is Stargorod, so you will be able to order some long waited food and beer straight after the your coding day.

To reserve a spot add a comment with your team name and a number of persons you will have in a team.

Let's the Tournament Begin!

P.S. Languages of the event will be ENG with Latvian and Russian translations for questions

events.name: MDL Meetup #10: Android
events.description:
FOR MDL EVENTS TO RESERVE A SEAT PLEASE REGISTER ON EVENTBRITE

Hey-hey, we're back from Summer vacation! And for the warm up, let's have an event fully dedicated to Android. Furthermore we will have 3 speakers instead of two and an awesome host¬†TestDevLab¬†who will be there all the time and eager to chat about Mobile development and testing.¬†

Sergejs Luhmirins¬†- Android over-engineer at FullContact

Architecture Components - What is it all about?

Opinionated look at recently introduced Android architecture components announced at Google I/O 2017. Some close-to-real-life examples and some conclusions from my experiments with Google's take on application architecture.

P.S. Expect Kotlin

Aleksandrs Orlovs¬†- Android Dev at Chili Labs

Android Data Binding Library¬†

‚ÄùData Binding Library‚Äù is a powerful tool to bind together your application logic and layouts. I will give a talk about ways to reduce a lot of the boiler code and pave a way to MVVM architectural pattern.¬†

Deniss Kaibagarovs¬†- Cross platforms developer at C.T.Co

iOS for Android Developer¬†

What is the difference between Android and iOS development? In this talk, I will try to give a brief introduction to iOS for Android Developers, and vice versa. You will discover both platforms basic components differences and similarities (Activity<->UIViewController, ListView<->UITableView, etc.). If you are far away from development, not a problem - you would walk away with a deeper understanding of both platforms.

events.name: MDL Meetup #11: iOS
events.description:
FOR MDL EVENTS TO RESERVE A SEAT PLEASE REGISTER ON¬†EVENTBRITE

Come and join us for a relaxed discussion related to iOS app development.¬†We will have 3 speakers instead of two this time and an awesome host¬†TestDevLab¬†who will be there all the time and eager to chat about Mobile development and testing.¬†

Kristaps Felzenbergs - Lead Security and Test Automation Engineer @¬†

TestDevLab

Reverse engineering of iOS apps to find security vulnerabilities¬†(ENG)

In this talk I will discuss ways how to debug iOS applications, what information can be extracted from them and show¬†live¬†demo of various tools that might come handy to address security issues and possible vulnerabilities in your app.

Igors ≈Öeme≈Üonoks - iOS Dev @¬†

Chili Labs

Let's do i< T > with generics¬†(ENG)

One of the most powerful features introduced in Swift was generic programming. Generic code allows you to write flexible, reusable functions and types while still maintaining the type safety that makes Swift awesome. In this talk, I‚Äôll cover what generics are and why you want to use them as well as discuss real-world examples where generics can be used.

Dmitrijs Beloborodovs¬†-¬†Passionate iOS developer

iOS 11: what's new and why it's next big thing¬†(ENG)

Will review what's new in iOS 11 and Xcode 9. Dive into "next big things" like augmented reality and machine learning. Talk about why it's important, how easy it is to adapt and¬†preview¬†latest available iOS beta.¬†Also lets¬†check some nice features in Xcode 9 and try few minor, but very cool improvements

Organizers:

Chili¬†- We make mobile apps and right now we are looking for experienced iOS and Android developers! For more info please visit this¬†page.

GDG Riga¬†-¬†to keep track for more events from GDG Riga, visit our website gdgriga.lv and follow us¬†on¬†the web!

Facebook:

Mobile Developers Latvia

GDG Riga

events.name: TGIF with GDG Tartu and Angular GDE
events.description:
To celebrate hitting our 700 member on Meetup and to make summer even hotter we have a very special event with 3 super speakers and GDG organizers from Tartu and Barcelona! This is an event you can not miss.

Tele2 Shared Service Center¬†are very kind to host us this time and will also celebrate our proud mark with some tasty pizzas! After the event be prepare for some IT pub crawl with speakers, it's TGIF after all ;)¬†

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Madis Pink - Android Developer at ZeroTurnaround

Madis is currently working on JRebel for Android at ZeroTurnaround and co-organizing the GDG Tartu chapter.

He started hacking on Android apps on a T-Mobile G1 more than 8 years ago and quickly grew a particular interest in build systems and developer tooling. His previous experience includes working on the Android Platform team at Spotify and working on multiple apps at Mobi Lab. During his free time he likes to dabble around with guitars and home recording.

Emojis! üéâüôåüòé

Over the past decade the popularity of emojis has grown from relative obscurity to a big-budget Hollywood picture üéûÔ∏è.

Emojis used to be solely in the domain of chat apps but these days any app having user generated content is expected to have emoji support.
In this session we'll take a technical look at how Emojis are represented in Unicode ü§ì, identify common pitfalls üêõ and find ways to circumvent them (pitfalls that is, not emojis üòé).

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Harri Kirik - Software engineer at Mobi Lab

Harri works as a software engineer in a digital design agency Mobi Lab. On free time he is also a GDG Tartu organizer.¬†

Two-factor authentication

Harri will talk about why two-factor authentication matters and how it is most commonly used on mobile phones.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Gerard Sans - Google Developer Expert Angular

Gerard¬†is a Computer Science Engineer & Google Developer Expert. As a community activist he is fighting for the JavaScript revolution. Having lived and worked for all sorts of companies over the world, he is always up for a good challenge. He likes running AngularZone and GraphQL London, mentoring students & participating in the community.

Implementing Motion using Angular (v4.3+)

In this talk we are going to cover some of the 12 principles behind UX Motion giving practical examples while integrating those incrementally into an App. We will focus on these UX Motion principles while covering some implementation details using the new animation features in Angular.

Also, Gerard is hosting a full day Angular workshop, if you want to learn more from him, definitely¬†apply!¬†https://www.meetup.com/GDG-Riga/events/242174096/
events.how_to_find_us: 3 floor building with Tele2 logo on the rooftop

events.name: Masterclass: Angular Extreme by Gerard Sans
events.description:
Gerard is a Computer Science Engineer & Google Developer Expert. As a community activist he is fighting for the JavaScript revolution. Having lived and worked for all sorts of companies over the world, he is always up for a good challenge. He likes running AngularZone and GraphQL London, mentoring students & participating in the community.

https://twitter.com/gerardsans¬†
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Masterclass¬†Angular Extreme

Masterclass Description: Angular is a robust platform and many products relay on its foundation. Teams have now learnt about best practices and tooling.

In this workshop you will learn about the less known areas of Angular so you can take your skills to the next level!

What you'll learn during the day:

New Features of Angular and new HTTPClient, do a codelab and have a Q&A session with Gerard about any Angular specific questions

Gerard Sans suddenly had to replan his day, so we will shorten the event to 2 hours and it will be free of charge

events.name: MDL Meetup #11: GDG Minsk Android

venue.name: OK.ru Office
venue.address_1: Pblc Biznesa Centrs , SIA - 23 Ulbrokas iela

events.description:
Yanina Belaziorava - Android Developer Sciencesoft (ENG)

Android¬†Instant App SDK¬†

Yanina is Android developer and big Android enthusiast. In the past she was also Android and Java mentor at a programmer school in Chicago. She is also interested in AI for Android, Android Things, Android Auto, applications for data transfer channels like Bluetooth and NFC. My experience building an Android Instant App Recently Google made Instant App SDK publicly available. I was excited about that and rushed to try it out. I used one of my existing apps to refactor for Instant App compatibility and extract an instant app flavor. I would like to share with you my experience as I was doing that.

Pavel Shchahelski - Android developer Netstream (ENG)

Kotlin: home fun part¬†

It is easy to translate Kotlin to java. It is funny how your code will look like after this translation. Together with the audience we will go and see what we have at the end. After we will try to benchmark what we have.

Yanina Belaziorava - Android Developer Sciencesoft (ENG)

Yanina is Android developer and big Android enthusiast. In the past she was also Android and Java mentor at a programmer school in Chicago. She is also interested in AI for Android, Android Things, Android Auto, applications for data transfer channels like Bluetooth and NFC. My experience building an Android Instant App Recently Google made Instant App SDK publicly available. I was excited about that and rushed to try it out. I used one of my existing apps to refactor for Instant App compatibility and extract an instant app flavor. I would like to share with you my experience as I was doing that.

Pavel Shchahelski - Android developer Netstream (ENG)

Love kittens Kotlin: home fun part 1 It is easy to translate kotlin to java. It is funny how your code will look like after this translation. Together with the audience we will go and see what we have at the end. After we will try to benchmark what we have.

events.name: Workshop: From Zero to Cluster in the Cloud with Terraform
events.description:
Managing cloud resources can be challenging when their number grows. How about managing deployments that span several clouds?

Join us and learn about Terraform - infrastructure-as-code tool that can manage hybrid configurations spanning different IaaS, PaaS or SaaS providers.

During this practical workshop, we will create fully-blown infrastructure with a set of simple configuration files using Terraform's a declarative syntax.

Don't miss out, and we'll see you there!

events.name: Workshop: Writing Firebase Functions in Kotlin
events.description:
Sergej Luhmirin has been developing¬†Android applications in multiple companies over the last 5+ years. Tinkering with Kotlin from its first public releases and using it in production application for the last 10 months. Occasionally giving presentations about Android and Kotlin related topics at developer meetups, such as this one!

https://twitter.com/luhmirins

About the workshop:

There is a lot of hype surrounding a serverless architecture, and for many products having dedicated servers might not be the most cost-effective.¬†

Such products are the perfect use case for Firebase, as Firebase Functions allow you to execute computation directly in the cloud without caring about instances, containers and other infrastructure details.¬†

There is also a lot of hype around Kotlin as well, and after the release of version 1.1 it is possible to transpile Kotlin code to Javascript.

In this workshop we will try combining both of these trendy technologies and see what happens!

As such we hope you will join us and we can take this journey together!

events.name: Workshop: Forget about frontend runtime errors with ELM
events.description:
About the speaker:¬†

JƒÅnis Miezƒ´tis. Works at Diatom Enterprises as a Software engineer. Traveled Latin America for a year with his wife. Former semi-professional MMA fighter. Excited about functional programming and writing reliable apps!

Also excited and hopeful to see you on Saturday, 4th of November, to share in his experience with Elm and try some things for yourself!¬†

https://twitter.com/janjiss

About the workshop:¬†

The talk itself will include comparison between ELM and JS, ELM and modern frontend frameworks, introduction to ELMs data types, syntax and a way of doing things. In the workshop we will be building a ToDo list app that will leverage local storage for data persistence.

Does that sound like something you'd be interested in? Join us, and we'll see you there!

Requirements:

Couple of years of experience in any mainstream programming language. Be it C#, JavaScript, Ruby or any other.

Go to this URL and follow setup instructions. Should work on Node above version 6. :
https://github.com/janjiss/todo-elm
If you see "Hello world", then it means you are good to go.¬†

Next, please take 5 minutes to read about ELMs basic data types. While not strictly necessary, it will be highly helpful to you :)
https://guide.elm-lang.org/core_language.html

events.name: DevFest Baltics 2017: Mobile Edition
events.description:
DevFest Baltics 2017 ‚Äî the first conference in the Baltics packed with topics about mobile development and Internet of Things organized by Google Developer Groups from the Baltics. Save the date and location: November 17, Riga.

DevFest Baltics will present 15 experienced speakers from all around the World who are true technology experts from Google, SoundCloud, Microsoft and other famous IT companies. Conference Program will present hottest trends and innovations of the following topics:

All about mobile development

- Android and iOS

- Mobile cross-platform tools

- UI/UX and prototyping

- Internet of Things

- VR and AR

- Bots, AI and more.

The early speakers Jozef Vodicka from Google (Czech Republic), Fernando Cejas from SoundCloud (Germany), Cesar Valentine from Microsoft (Germany), Manu Wallner from Fastlane (Austria) will rock on the stage, but there will be much more!

In other words DevFest Baltics is an event that you simply cannot miss if you love Mobile! The ticket sales are starting very soon, but for now you can stay tuned and follow DevFest Baltics on Twitter, Facebook and devfest.gdg.lv

The conference organizers are seeking for industry advocates with inspiring and insightful knowledge and vision. DevFest Baltics call for speaker proposals is open till October the 1st but most of the program will be announced earlier. If you are tech enthusiast who have something to share about listed topics, do not miss the chance to apply.

There is also a great opportunity for organizations who care about local IT community development to become a partner of DevFest Baltics and make the event even more memorable and useful. If you are interested in helping us make the conference better, please contact us at [masked].

About organizer:

Google Developers Group (GDG) - is an open and volunteer geek community who create exciting projects and share experience about Google technologies with a passion. GDG have two chapters in Latvia, GDG Riga and GDG Daugavpils. Both of them are proud to be organizers of DevFest Baltics.

For more information, sign up to our mailing list or contact [masked]¬†

DISCLAIMER: –¢–æ organize such a big event, book flights and hotels to speakers, book the venue and tech needed, order food, swag, etc we need additional funds, so the event will feature a minimal price to cover the expenses. Please follow up our website with updates on that and be the first to get the ticket to DevFest!

events.name: DevFest Baltics 2017: Unconference
events.description:
DevFest Baltics Unconference is unique place where you can socialize ask questions to speakers from DevFest Baltics and present you own ideas. The event is a satellite event to DevFest Baltics and is free to attend to anyone with or without a ticket

If you would like to present a lightning talk (15 min), please fill <a>http:///ej.uz/SpeakAtGDG</a>¬†and we will contact you shortly! The talk must be about development or development practices.

1. talk from George Eid

Founder/CEO AREA 17

Starting a digital agency without losing your soul

An open discussion on how to run a mission-based digital agency. This is not a presentation, but rather an opportunity for anyone interested in opening their own agency to ask a 25 year veteran any questions they may have ‚Äì¬†from choosing the right clients to process and even money talk.¬†

2. talk from Marcin Krzyzanowski

Marcin Krzy≈ºanowski, PSPDFKit GmbH. A software developer who works on mobile applications in these days. With the head full of ideas, in the spare time, he creates new projects and contributes himself back to OSS community. The author of Natalie, CryptoSwift, and ObjectivePGP. Trying to bring privacy to the masses with privacyapp.io. Infrequent blogger.

Decipher the encoding

What is the difference¬†between encoding and encryption? what is encoding and how it works? in this that you‚Äôll find the answer to those questions, with an examples and comments.

3. talk will be presented by¬†Filip Proch√°zka

GDG Pilsen Organizer and Android Developer at Ubiquiti Networks

Let's get high with Kodein

Kodein is a dependency injection framework, written entirely in and best used with Kotlin programming language. I will show you how it works and compare it with Dagger 2.

More talks will be announced soon!

Keep following for updates!

events.name: Hash Code 2018
events.description:
Hash Code is a team programming competition organized by Google. You pick your team and programming language, we pick a Google engineering problem for you to solve.
Are you up for the challenge?

Top scoring teams from the Online Qualification Round will be notified and invited to the Final Round at Google Dublin on 28th of April!

What do I need to participate?

!!! Important !!!: You need to register at HashCode website (https://hashcode.withgoogle.com/)

P.S. Register before 1st of February and get a cool HashCode swag directly from Google ;)

The only thing you need for the Online Qualification Round is a computer connected to the Internet. We will announce the problem through a YouTube Live Stream. The Judge System will be available as a web application, compatible with recent web browsers. For the rest of your computer setup, you're free to use the tools and programming languages of your choice.

Agenda:

‚Ä¢ 19:00:Venue opens

‚Ä¢ 19:30:Live stream starts

‚Ä¢ 19:45:Task made available, competition starts

‚Ä¢ 23:30:End of the competition

More info on https://hashcode.withgoogle.com/

‚Ä¢ What to bring
Laptops and team spirit!

events.name: Google Cloud Study Jam
events.description:
Study Jams are community-run study groups for developers on Google Developers content, on various product topics.
The objective of Study Jams is to raise the technical proficiency of our global community members through the highest possible course completion rate.

You will:
-Learn how to set up development and production environments in the Cloud.
-Learn how Docker and Kubernetes work, or learn how to process Big Data in the Cloud.
-Get access to Qwiklabs, a Google training tool, free of charge (a $70+ value).
-Get Google-hosted badges for your online profile, to show potential employers what you know about Cloud computing.

What you'll need:
Laptop to work on.

in a colorful community bus! It will stop in in Riga on 6th June.

Join the Community Roadshow to find out how Google supports developer communities and start-ups. Meet community members, take part in workshops and have fun with live music and games on site.

Cloud), and meet with Google teams

events.name: Android Things workshop
events.description:
Android Things workshop

ATTENTION: Venue has changed to TechHub Riga, Sporta iela 2

Unique opportunity to take part in Android Things workshop.
Pico Pro Maker developer kit will be be provided to build a product of your dreams.

Android Things lets you build professional, mass-market products on a trusted platform, without previous knowledge of embedded system design.
Kits enable you to easily start developing your own prototype. Once you are ready to create a product, you can effortlessly move your code to a production board.

Important: Special prizes from Google for the most studious attendees.

We provide:
Pico Pro Maker Kit

Bring with you:
Laptop with Android Studio 3.0 or later installed

Android Things Get Started link:
https://developer.android.com/things/get-started/

Workshop is organized by Google Developer Group Riga.

events.name: Reliability Engineering @ Google
events.description:
Reliability is a first-class concern for Google services and at Google scale of systems operations. We will look at Reliability Engineering principles and practices Google employs, including product development and operations alignment, using software engineering to solve operations problems, measuring systems reliability, error budgets, change management, and incident response. There also will be time to ask questions, discuss problems audience faces in these areas and ponder on applying the same principles in your organizations

Aleksejs Truhans
Senior Software Engineer
Serverless Platform SRE Team

Aleksejs is a software engineer in the team responsible for control planes used across Google Serverless products. Previously, Aleksejs worked on Google App Engine request serving reliability.

Prior to Google, Aleksejs was a software developer, analyst, and engineering manager in Latvian banks and enjoyed teaching programming courses.

events.name: DevFest Baltics 2018

venue.name: Baltic Beach SPA and Resort Hotel

events.description:
DevFest Baltics 2018 ‚Äî the first conference in the Baltics packed with topics about mobile development and Internet of Things organized by Google Developer Groups from the Baltics. Save the date and location: November 16, Jurmala.

DevFest Baltics will present 15 experienced speakers from all around the World who are true technology experts. Conference Program will present hottest trends and innovations of the following topics:

All about mobile development

- Android and iOS
- Mobile cross-platform tools
- UI/UX and prototyping
- Internet of Things
- VR and AR
- Bots, AI and more.

In other words DevFest Baltics is an event that you simply cannot miss if you love Mobile! The ticket sales are starting very soon, but for now you can stay tuned and follow DevFest Baltics on Twitter (https://twitter.com/devfestbaltics), Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/devfestbaltics/) and devfest.gdg.lv (https://devfest.gdg.lv/)

The conference organizers are seeking for industry advocates with inspiring and insightful knowledge and vision. DevFest Baltics call for speaker proposals is open and most of the program will be announced soon. If you are tech enthusiast who have something to share about listed topics, do not miss the chance to apply (https://www.papercall.io/devfest-baltics-18).

There is also a great opportunity for organizations who care about local IT community development to become a partner of DevFest Baltics and make the event even more memorable and useful. If you are interested in helping us make the conference better, please contact us at [masked].

About organizer:

Google Developers Group (GDG) - is an open and volunteer geek community who create exciting projects and share experience about Google technologies with a passion. GDG have two chapters in Latvia, GDG Riga (http://gdgdriga.lv/) and GDG Daugavpils (http://daugavpils.gdg.lv/). Both of them are proud to be organizers of DevFest Baltics.

For more information, sign up to our mailing list or contact [masked]

events.name: Workshop: Swift Design Patterns by Paul Hudson

venue.name: Baltic Beach SPA and Resort Hotel

events.description:
This Workshop is organized along DevFest Baltics (devfest.gdg.lv), a conference for Mobile developers by Mobile developers. This Workshop is a paid event with all the income going to booking venue and covering expenses for speakers.

TICKET LINK: https://www.xing-events.com/DevFestBaltics2018.html
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
About speaker:

Paul is the author of Hacking with Swift, Pro Swift, Swift Design Patterns, Server-Side Swift, Hacking with macOS, Hacking with watchOS, Hacking with tvOS, Swift Coding Challenges, and more. Suffice it to say, he quite likes Swift. And coffee. (But mostly Swift.) (And coffee.)
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
You can also follow Paul:

- On Twitter: @twostraws
- Or follow Paul's blog: https://www.hackingwithswift.com
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
About the Workshop:

Regardless of how you approach coding, everyone agrees that code ought to be reusable. That might mean creating a class hierarchy, it might mean using protocol-oriented programming, it might mean using generics, or any number of other techniques ‚Äì they all make code useful in more than once place.

A design pattern is the ability to reuse ideas. It‚Äôs the ability to say ‚Äúlast time we hit a problem similar to this, we solved it by‚Ä¶‚Äù and then outlining a solution you know to have worked previously. You never remember the exact code you wrote, but you do remember your structure, the advantages, the disadvantages, and any implications for the rest of your project.

A design pattern is the ability to say to say, ‚Äúwe can solve this using a template method,‚Äù and have everyone else understand what you mean ‚Äì and understand the same advantages, disadvantages, and implications that you had in your head. We all take this kind of shared vocabulary for granted when talking about things like classes, generics, and extensions ‚Äì things that have entirely different meanings outside of programming ‚Äì and it‚Äôs just as useful when applied to ideas.

In this workshop you‚Äôll get hands-on examples of the most important patterns available to Swift developers, so you can try using them, re-using them, and refactoring them into your own work.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
TICKET LINK: https://www.xing-events.com/DevFestBaltics2018.html

events.name: Build your first Android app!

venue.name: Baltic Beach SPA and Resort Hotel

events.description:
Have you ever wondered how to write an Android app? Is it as easy as some people say?
Let‚Äôs find out together at this workshop organised by Women Techmakers Latvia!

In this event we will:
- learn about basic parts that make up any Android app;
- learn some Kotlin - official and awesome programming language for Android development;
- create a simple note taking app to have hands-on experience.

Programming experience is not required, but it will be an advantage.

Please bring:
- laptop with Android studio installed (d.android.com/studio);
- Android phone and USB wire to connect it to your laptop.

Recommended preparation:
Because first run of the application may require extra downloads and since conference space Wi-Fi is usually pretty limited it is preferable to do basic project setup. Just click through (Next, next, next, finish, wait, Run->Run). Do not be discouraged if you do not understand something, it is not important right now, just make it run - https://developer.android.com/studio/projects/create-project

Workshop could be held in English/Latvian/Russian (depending on attendee preference) and led by Sergejs Luhmirins - Android developer at Chili Labs (https://chi.lv/).

Where? Baltic Beach Hotel & SPA, J≈´ras iela 23/25, Jurmala-2015
When? November 17, 10:00 ‚Äì 14:00

About speaker:
I have been developing Android applications in multiple companies over last 5+ years. Tinkering with Kotlin from the first public releases and using it in production applications for the last few years. Occasionally giving presentations about Kotlin related topics at local developer meetups.

events.name: Forget RxJava: Kotlin coroutines are all you need
events.description:
Let's start our new 2019 GDG Riga season with a impromptu guest lecture from our friend from abroad, Vladimir.

Topic: Forget RxJava: Kotlin coroutines are all you need

65% of developers starting #Kotlin project choose RxJava 2 as a background work tool. But are you sure the choice is justified? Kotlin coroutines can be a powerful replacement for RxJava in an Android project. In this talk, we are going to compare the approaches, consider their pros and cons, and see when coroutines are more convenient, and when you are doomed without Rx. We will also see how unit testing differs between two approaches and how they can live together in a project.

Vladimir Ivanov is a lead software engineer in EPAM Systems, Google Cloud Certified Architect and a program committee member of biggest mobile conference in Russia - https://mobiusconf.com/. Started as a Java EE engineer, but got interested in mobile technologies, Vladimir develops Android apps mostly last 7 years, but looks around and comprehends nearby technologies like React Native, iOS app development, web development, etc. Vladimir is passionate about sharing his knowledge.

events.name: Hash Code 2019
events.description:
Hash Code is a team programming competition organized by Google. You pick your team and programming language, we pick a Google engineering problem for you to solve.
Are you up for the challenge?

Top scoring teams from the Online Qualification Round will be notified and invited to the Final Round at Google Dublin on 28th of April!

What do I need to participate?

!!! Important !!!: You need to register at HashCode website (https://hashcode.withgoogle.com/) before Feb 25, 2019

The only thing you need for the Online Qualification Round is a computer connected to the Internet. We will announce the problem through a YouTube Live Stream. The Judge System will be available as a web application, compatible with recent web browsers. For the rest of your computer setup, you're free to use the tools and programming languages of your choice.

Location: Riga, Republikas laukums 3. Ieeja no krastmalas, koda vƒÅrds apsargam: ‚ÄúCitadele MƒÅcƒ´bu Centrs‚Äù

More info on https://hashcode.withgoogle.com/

Study Jams are community-run study groups for developers on Google Developers content, on various product topics.
The objective of Study Jams is to raise the technical proficiency of our global community members through the highest possible course completion rate.

You will:
